metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: To fill a table in MySQL, use the "INSERT INTO" statement.
content.html: To fill a table in MySQL, use the "INSERT INTO" statement.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import mysql.connectormydb = mysql.connector.connect(  host="localhost",
   
  user="yourusername",  password="yourpassword",  database="mydatabase")
  mycursor = mydb.cursor()sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, 
  address) VALUES (%s, %s)"val = ("John", "Highway 21")mycursor.execute(sql, 
  val)
  mydb.commit()print(mycursor.rowcount, "record inserted.")

val)

 mycursor = mydb.cursor()sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name,

content.code_html:
import mysql.connector

mydb = mysql.connector.connect(
  host="localhost",
  user="yourusername",
  password="yourpassword",
  database="mydatabase"
)

mycursor = mydb.cursor()

sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, address) VALUES (%s, %s)"
val = ("John", "Highway 21")
mycursor.execute(sql, val)

mydb.commit()

print(mycursor.rowcount, "record inserted.")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import mysql.connectormydb = mysql.connector.connect(  host="localhost",
   
  user="yourusername",  password="yourpassword",  database="mydatabase")
  mycursor = mydb.cursor()sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, 
  address) VALUES (%s, %s)"val = ("John", "Highway 21")mycursor.execute(sql, 
  val)
  mydb.commit()print(mycursor.rowcount, "record inserted.")

content.text: Important!: Notice the statement: mydb.commit() . It is required to make the changes, otherwise no changes are made to the table.
content.html: Important!: Notice the statement: mydb.commit(). It is required to make the changes, otherwise no changes are made to the table.

content.text: To insert multiple rows into a table, use the executemany() method.
content.html: To insert multiple rows into a table, use the executemany() method.

content.text: The second parameter of the executemany() method is a list of tuples, containing the data you want to insert:
content.html: The second parameter of the executemany() method is a list of tuples, containing the data you want to insert:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import mysql.connectormydb = mysql.connector.connect(  host="localhost",
   
  user="yourusername",  password="yourpassword",  database="mydatabase")
  mycursor = mydb.cursor()sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, 
  address) VALUES (%s, %s)"val = [  ('Peter', 'Lowstreet 4'),  
  ('Amy', 'Apple st 652'),  ('Hannah', 'Mountain 21'),  
  ('Michael', 'Valley 345'),  ('Sandy', 'Ocean blvd 2'),  
  ('Betty', 'Green Grass 1'),  ('Richard', 'Sky st 331'),  
  ('Susan', 'One way 98'),  ('Vicky', 'Yellow Garden 2'),  
  ('Ben', 'Park Lane 38'),  ('William', 'Central st 954'),  
  ('Chuck', 'Main Road 989'),  ('Viola', 'Sideway 1633')]
  mycursor.executemany(sql, val)mydb.commit()print(mycursor.rowcount, "was inserted.")

content.code_html:
import mysql.connector

mydb = mysql.connector.connect(
  host="localhost",
  user="yourusername",
  password="yourpassword",
  database="mydatabase"
)

mycursor = mydb.cursor()

sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, address) VALUES (%s, %s)"
val = [
  ('Peter', 'Lowstreet 4'),
  ('Amy', 'Apple st 652'),
  ('Hannah', 'Mountain 21'),
  ('Michael', 'Valley 345'),
  ('Sandy', 'Ocean blvd 2'),
  ('Betty', 'Green Grass 1'),
  ('Richard', 'Sky st 331'),
  ('Susan', 'One way 98'),
  ('Vicky', 'Yellow Garden 2'),
  ('Ben', 'Park Lane 38'),
  ('William', 'Central st 954'),
  ('Chuck', 'Main Road 989'),
  ('Viola', 'Sideway 1633')
]

mycursor.executemany(sql, val)

mydb.commit()

print(mycursor.rowcount, "was inserted.")

content.text: You can get the id of the row you just inserted by asking the cursor object.
content.html: You can get the id of the row you just inserted by asking the cursor object.

content.text: Note: If you insert more than one row, the id of the last inserted row is returned.
content.html: Note: If you insert more than one row, the id of the last inserted row is returned.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import mysql.connectormydb = mysql.connector.connect(  host="localhost",
   
  user="yourusername",  password="yourpassword",  database="mydatabase")
  mycursor = mydb.cursor()sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, 
  address) VALUES (%s, %s)"val = ("Michelle", "Blue Village")
  mycursor.execute(sql, val)mydb.commit()print("1 record 
  inserted, ID:", mycursor.lastrowid)

content.code_html:
import mysql.connector

mydb = mysql.connector.connect(
  host="localhost",
  user="yourusername",
  password="yourpassword",
  database="mydatabase"
)

mycursor = mydb.cursor()

sql = "INSERT INTO customers (name, address) VALUES (%s, %s)"
val = ("Michelle", "Blue Village")
mycursor.execute(sql, val)

mydb.commit()

print("1 record inserted, ID:", mycursor.lastrowid)
